source.3e523284:
def func(x):
    if x =='Man':
        return "Male"
    elif x =='Woman':
        return "Female"
    else:
        return "Others"
data['gender']=data['Q2'].apply(func)
genderlist=data['gender'].unique()

# Creating plot 
fig = plt.figure(figsize =(6, 6)) 
explode = (0.1, 0.1, 0.1)  

#my_colors = ['lightblue', 'lightpink','lightgreen']
colors = ['#ffcc99','#66b3ff','#99ff99']
wedges, texts, autotexts=plt.pie(data['gender'].value_counts(),autopct='%1.1f%%',explode=explode,colors=colors, startangle=15, shadow = True,textprops=dict(color="w")) 

for text in texts:
    text.set_color('black')
for autotext in autotexts:
    autotext.set_color('black')
    
plt.title('Gender Ratio')
plt.axis('equal')
plt.legend(wedges, genderlist,
          title="Gender",
          loc="center left",
          bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0, 0.5, 1))
# show plot 
plt.show()
source.b94613c1:
from palettable.colorbrewer.qualitative import Pastel1_7

jobprofile=data['Q5'].unique()


# Creating plot 
fig = plt.figure(figsize =(6, 6)) 

my_circle=plt.Circle( (0,0), 3, color='white')


#my_colors = ['lightblue', 'lightpink','lightgreen']
wedges, texts, autotexts=plt.pie(data['Q5'].value_counts(),autopct='%1.1f%%',startangle=15,wedgeprops=dict(width=0.60) ,colors=Pastel1_7.hex_colors,shadow = True,textprops=dict(color="black")) 
 
plt.title('Job Profile')
plt.axis('equal')
plt.legend(wedges, jobprofile,
          title="Job Profile",
          loc="center left",
          bbox_to_anchor=(1, 0, 0.5, 1))

# show plot 
plt.show()
source.0b85e59d:
#bar chart : top 5 countries by number of people
import seaborn as sns
sns.set(style="darkgrid")
#titanic = sns.load_dataset("titanic")
#ax = sns.countplot(x="Q3", data=data)
count_filtered=data[data.Q3!="Other"]
freq_resp  = count_filtered['Q3'].value_counts()
freq_resp = freq_resp[:5,]
plt.figure(figsize=(10,5))
c=sns.barplot(freq_resp.index, freq_resp.values, alpha=0.8)
plt.title('Top 5 countries',  size=20)
plt.ylabel('Number of People', fontsize=12)
plt.xlabel('Countries', fontsize=12)
for p in c.patches:
             c.annotate("%.0f" % p.get_height(), (p.get_x() + p.get_width() / 2., p.get_height()),
                 ha='center', va='center', fontsize=10, color='black', xytext=(0, 5),
                 textcoords='offset points')

plt.show()

source.5da35a02:
# group age 
def func(x):
    if x =='18-21' or x =='22-24':
        return "<25"
    elif x =='25-29' or x =='30-34' or x =='35-39':
        return "25-39"
    elif  x =='40-44' or x =='45-49' or x =='50-54' :
        return "40-54"
    else:
        return "55+"
data['age_grouped']=data['Q1'].apply(func)

#group profession
def func(x):
    if x in ["Data Engineer","Data Scientist","Data Analyst","Statistician","Machine Learning Engineer","Business Analyst" ,"DBA/Database Engineer"]:
        return("Data Related profession")
    else:
        return x
data['profession_grouped']=data['Q5'].apply(func)


df_prof=data[["id","profession_grouped","Q7_Part_1", "Q7_Part_2"]]
df_prof_unpivoted = df_prof.melt(id_vars=['id','profession_grouped'], var_name='Option', value_name='Language')
#df_lang_unpivoted.sort_values(by=['id'])



df_lang=data[["id","age_grouped","Q7_Part_1", "Q7_Part_2"]]
df_lang_unpivoted = df_lang.melt(id_vars=['id','age_grouped'], var_name='Option', value_name='Language')
#df_lang_unpivoted.sort_values(by=['id'])

language_list=["id","profession_grouped", "Q4", "Q6", "age_grouped", "Q24"]
for col in data.columns:
    if 'Q7' in col:
          language_list.append(col)
            
#metric_cols=["id","profession_grouped", "Q4"]  

df_lang_all=data[language_list]
      
df_lang_unpivoted_all = df_lang_all.melt(id_vars=["id","profession_grouped", "Q4", "Q6", "age_grouped", "Q24"], var_name='Option', value_name='Language')
#df_lang_unpivoted.sort_values(by=['id'])

      
plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
c=sns.countplot(x="Language",data=df_lang_unpivoted_all,alpha=0.8, hue="Language", dodge=False, palette="muted",order=df_lang_unpivoted_all.Language.value_counts().iloc[:].index)
#plt.xticks(rotation=20)
plt.title('Language Distribution Overall',fontsize=15 )
plt.ylabel('Number of People', fontsize=12)
plt.xlabel('Language', fontsize=12)
for p in c.patches:
             c.annotate("%.0f" % p.get_height(), (p.get_x() + p.get_width() / 2., p.get_height()),
                 ha='center', va='center', fontsize=10, color='black', xytext=(0, 5),
                 textcoords='offset points')

plt.show()
source.fbb885b3:
# language used commonly by age


age_order=["<25","25-39","40-54","55+"]

plt.figure(figsize=(10,5))
c=sns.countplot(x="age_grouped",data=df_lang_unpivoted,alpha=0.8, hue="Language", order=age_order)
plt.title('Language Distribution by age group')
plt.ylabel('Number of People', fontsize=12)
plt.xlabel('Age Group', fontsize=12)
#for p in c.patches:
             #c.annotate("%.0f" % p.get_height(), (p.get_x() + p.get_width() / 2., p.get_height()),
                 #ha='center', va='center', fontsize=10, color='black', xytext=(0, 5),
                 #textcoords='offset points')
bars = c.patches
half = int(len(bars)/2)
left_bars = bars[:half]
right_bars = bars[half:]

for left, right in zip(left_bars, right_bars):
 height_l = left.get_height()
 height_r = right.get_height()
 total = height_l + height_r
 c.text(left.get_x() + left.get_width()/2., height_l + 40, '{0:.0%}'.format(height_l/total), ha="center")
 c.text(right.get_x() + right.get_width()/2., height_r + 40, '{0:.0%}'.format(height_r/total), ha="center")


plt.show()
source.56a54092:
# language used commonly by profession





plt.figure(figsize=(20,5))
c=sns.countplot(x="profession_grouped",data=df_prof_unpivoted,alpha=0.8, hue="Language")
#for p in c.patches:
             #c.annotate("%.0f" % p.get_height(), (p.get_x() + p.get_width() / 2., p.get_height()),
                 #ha='center', va='center', fontsize=10, color='black', xytext=(0, 5),
                 #textcoords='offset points')
bars = c.patches
half = int(len(bars)/2)
left_bars = bars[:half]
right_bars = bars[half:]

for left, right in zip(left_bars, right_bars):
 height_l = left.get_height()
 height_r = right.get_height()
 total = height_l + height_r
 c.text(left.get_x() + left.get_width()/2., height_l + 40, '{0:.0%}'.format(height_l/total), ha="center")
 c.text(right.get_x() + right.get_width()/2., height_r + 40, '{0:.0%}'.format(height_r/total), ha="center")
plt.title('Language Distribution by profession',fontsize=15 )
plt.ylabel('Number of People', fontsize=12)
plt.xlabel('Profession', fontsize=12)
plt.show()
source.4c875468:
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2,1,figsize=(25,12))
# excluding less than 1 year as count is zero ,"I have never written code"is also zero
coding_order=["1-2 years","3-5 years","5-10 years","10-20 years","20+ years"]
fig.suptitle("Language Distribution by Age vs Coding Age ", fontsize=20)
#plt.figure(figsize=(20,5))
sns.countplot(y="Q6",data=df_lang_unpivoted_all,alpha=0.8, hue="Language", dodge=False,order=coding_order, palette="deep", ax=axes[0])
#plt.xticks(rotation=20)
axes[0].set_title('Language Distribution by Coding Experience',fontsize=15 )
axes[0].set_xlabel('Number of People', fontsize=15)
axes[0].set_ylabel('Years of Coding Experience', fontsize=15)

age_order=["<25","25-39","40-54","55+"]
sns.countplot(y="age_grouped",data=df_lang_unpivoted_all,alpha=0.8, hue="Language", order=age_order,dodge=False, palette="deep", ax=axes[1])
#plt.xticks(rotation=20)
axes[1].set_title('Language Distribution by Age',fontsize=15 )
axes[1].set_xlabel('Number of People', fontsize=15)
axes[1].set_ylabel('Age', fontsize=15)

plt.show()
source.52432be1:
# coding age vs age
fig, axes = plt.subplots(1,2,figsize=(25,12))
salary_range=["100,000-124,999","125,000-149,999","150,000-199,999","200,000-249,999","250,000-299,999", "300,000-500,000","> $500,000" ]
age_order=["<25","25-39","40-54","55+"]
filtered_data = data[data['Q24'].isin(salary_range)]

fig.suptitle("Is Coding age more important than age ", fontsize=20)
#plt.figure(figsize=(20,5))
g=sns.countplot(x="age_grouped", data=filtered_data,alpha=0.8, hue="Q24",hue_order=salary_range,order=age_order, dodge=True, palette="muted", ax=axes[0])
plt.xticks(rotation=20)
axes[0].set_title('Salary Distribution by Age',fontsize=15 )
axes[0].set_xlabel('Age', fontsize=15)
axes[0].set_ylabel('Salary Range', fontsize=15)

leg = g.axes.get_legend()
new_title = 'Salary Range'
leg.set_title(new_title)
# Since <1 year and 20+ years have zero count excluding those in visual 
coding_order=["I have never written code","1-2 years","3-5 years","5-10 years","10-20 years"]
c=sns.countplot(x="Q6", data=filtered_data,alpha=0.8, hue="Q24", hue_order=salary_range,order=coding_order, dodge=True, palette="muted", ax=axes[1])
plt.xticks(rotation=20)
axes[1].set_title('Salary Distribution by Coding Age',fontsize=15 )
axes[1].set_xlabel('Coding Age', fontsize=15)
axes[1].set_ylabel('Salary Range', fontsize=15)
#plt.xticks(rotation=45)
leg = c.axes.get_legend()
new_title = 'Salary Range'
leg.set_title(new_title)



plt.show()

# ML algorithms preferred 
MLalgo=["id","profession_grouped", "Q4", "Q6", "age_grouped", "Q24", "Q15"]
for col in data.columns:
    if 'Q17' in col:
          MLalgo.append(col)
             

MLalgo_all=data[MLalgo]
      
MLalgo_unpivoted_all = MLalgo_all.melt(id_vars=["id","profession_grouped", "Q4", "Q6", "age_grouped", "Q24", "Q15"], var_name='Option', value_name='ML_Algorithm')


plt.figure(figsize=(20,5))

c=sns.countplot(x="ML_Algorithm", data=MLalgo_unpivoted_all,alpha=0.7, hue="ML_Algorithm", dodge=False, palette="muted", order=MLalgo_unpivoted_all.ML_Algorithm.value_counts().iloc[:5].index)
plt.title('Top 5 ML Algorithms preferred by people', fontsize=15)
plt.xticks(rotation=10)
plt.ylabel('Number of People', fontsize=15)
for p in c.patches:
             c.annotate("%.0f" % p.get_height(), (p.get_x() + p.get_width() / 2., p.get_height()),
                 ha='center', va='center', fontsize=10, color='black', xytext=(0, 5),
                 textcoords='offset points')
plt.legend([],[], frameon=False)
plt.show()

for col in data.columns:
    if 'Q29' in col:
          bd.append(col)
             

df_bd_all=data[bd]
      
df_bd_unpivoted_all = df_bd_all.melt(id_vars=["profession_grouped",  "age_grouped","Q20" ], var_name='Option', value_name='BD_Product')

# by Age
plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
age_order=["<25","25-39","40-54","55+"]
sns.countplot(y="BD_Product", data=df_bd_unpivoted_all,alpha=0.7,hue="age_grouped" , dodge=False,hue_order=age_order, palette="muted",order=df_bd_unpivoted_all.BD_Product.value_counts().index) 
plt.title('Popular Big Data Products people want to learn in next 2 years', fontsize=15)
plt.ylabel('Product', fontsize=15)
plt.xlabel('Number of People', fontsize=15)
#plt.xticks(rotation=90)
#plt.legend([],[], frameon=False)
plt.show()
source.e3e17959:
# BI

bi=["profession_grouped",  "age_grouped","Q20" ]
for col in data.columns:
    if 'Q31' in col:
          bi.append(col)
             

df_bi_all=data[bi]
      
df_bi_unpivoted_all = df_bi_all.melt(id_vars=["profession_grouped",  "age_grouped","Q20" ], var_name='Option', value_name='BITool')

# by Age
plt.figure(figsize=(15,5))
age_order=["<25","25-39","40-54","55+"]
sns.countplot(y="BITool", data=df_bi_unpivoted_all,alpha=0.7,hue="age_grouped" , dodge=False,hue_order=age_order, palette="muted",order=df_bi_unpivoted_all.BITool.value_counts().index) 
plt.title('Popular Business Intelligence people want to learn in next 2 years', fontsize=15)
plt.ylabel('BI Tool', fontsize=15)
plt.xlabel('Number of People', fontsize=15)
#plt.xticks(rotation=90)
#plt.legend([],[], frameon=False)
plt.show()
source.9cfe948c:
# Distribution by  Profession

Data Science seems to be more popular with aspiring students. They are the generation which is able to forsee this disruptive transformation and a generation which wants everything **Easy**. The generation that people love to hate is known for being early adopters of new technologies
This may be a factor responsible for trend of more and more [colleges offering Data Science](https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/why-more-colleges-are-offering-data-science-programs).
source.b9c07e25:
# Distribution by Gender in the Top 5 countries

Irrespective of country, male population is approximately 80%  which is close to overall percentage when all countries are combined. Irrspective of country Data Science is male dominated and 4 in every 5 data scientists  happen to be male. According to this [article](https://www.betterbuys.com/bi/women-in-data-science/) a study by harvard women mentions that women with 8 years of programming experience are as confident as men with one year of programming experience. The question is what is it which makes men more risk taking and leads them to easily adopt to new technologies more? Is it social setup or it is in genes?
source.d9216249: Understanding and Analyzing data is top most key component at work. In the book Doing Data Science authored by Cathy O'Neil, Rachel Schutt Data science activities are expressed as “More generally, a data scientist is someone who knows how to extract meaning from and interpret data, which requires both tools and methods from statistics and machine learning, as well as being human. She spends a lot of time in the process of collecting, cleaning, and munging data, because data is never clean. This process requires persistence, statistics, and software engineering skills—skills that are also necessary for understanding biases in the data, and for debugging logging output from code".
source.8c492c18:
# Drill down into student and Data Science community on basis of ML Algo used commonly
The same preference can be seen in Student and Data science community where more numbers are for Linear or logistic regression. Even though Bayesian approaches are more reliable, but it is complex and computationally intense and that could be a probable reason behind low numbers. A really simple explanation of Bayesian method can be read at [analytics vidhya](https://www.analyticsvidhya.com/blog/2016/06/bayesian-statistics-beginners-simple-english/)
source.dcdedd46:
## Bridging the Gender Gap!!

Data Science; and programming in general was assumed to be a Man's  world. But did you know, the first program was actually written by a woman! As per Wikipedia, **Ada Lovelace** has been called the world's first computer programmer. What she did was write the world's first machine algorithm for an early computing machine that existed only on paper. Of course, someone had to be the first, but Lovelace was a woman, and this was in the 1840s.  Let's try to see what is the distribution  by gender in the data that we have. There is steady increase in numbers from 16.71% in 2017 to current 19.36% in 2020 as evident from an analysis of fellow [kagglers](https://www.kaggle.com/aagghh/animated-plots-and-kaggle-surveys#section-three) in an animated visual "Respondents' sex change over time". Irrespective of steady  increase it is still a long way and there are factors which keep Women away from Data science and representation of other genders is very low. An interesting read about [what keeps women away](https://www.bcg.com/publications/2020/what-keeps-women-out-data-science) and current gender gap in 2020  analysis by fellow [Kaggler](https://www.kaggle.com/lucabasa/gender-gap-in-the-kaggle-community)
source.6155b862:
# Coding Language Preference by Age ( R vs Python)

Our data reveals python as more popular than R across different age groups. Although younger people are more inclined for Python.
A [good blog](https://blog.simpliv.com/should-i-learn-python-or-r-for-data-science/) to compare two languages on various parameters focus on Python being more **easy** to use.
source.ecc6bf41:
There appears a linear relationship between data science team size and company size. Larger companies have bigger data science teams.
According to [candor.co](https://candor.co/articles/career-paths/data-science-careers-does-company-size-matter) "World-class, large companies like Uber, Airbnb, Facebook, and Google have dedicated technical teams led by industry elites".

source.28379b4b:
Coursera, Kaggle Learn Courses and Udemy are stepping stones where people start their Data Science journey. They are tightly followed by University Courses and DataCamp. Our data is in line with  the Top 8 Online Data Science courses as mentioned in [learndatasci.com ](http://www.learndatasci.com/best-data-science-online-courses/
). It is surprising to see that the Kaggle has not been listed in this article, though it seems to be highly popular among  aspiring Data Scientists.
source.609e9588:
# Is ability to code an essential skill in the future? Are Coders already being paid more?

The percentage of high salary in age<25 is way more and same goes for 3-5 years of coding experience. There is surprisingly high salary for people who have never coded. It may be due to the fact of automation tools which require low coding experience. Salary or your coding age may not be reason for your high pay.

source.babf2bd9: SQL based databases seem to be popular database with MongoDB as next in line. That raises a key question Do companies really have Big data Skills. According to [stitchdata ](https://www.stitchdata.com/blog/how-many-companies-actually-have-big-data-skills/)answer is "yes" but we are still at beginning stages and not many players.
source.dec38e2e: # Battle to STAY RELEVANT is fiercer than ever!!
source.5d665847:
# **Digital Disruption: The Rise of Digital Transformation**

What is **Digital Disruption**? What is **Digital Transformation**? How is this relevant in today's world? Is this relevant to me, does it affect me?

I hope you have this plethora of questions in your mind  when you read this heading? In today's world, each industry is heading towards digital. Everything is going online, EVERYBODY is going ONLINE. This massive shift in the work paradigm and meeting of what was earlier business in silos and using Digital Technology is what is called Digital Transformation. The current Covid Pandemic has accelerated this shift at pace no one imagined before. Who would have thought that Elementary Schools would have to turn Digital? 

How is this Disruptive? Let's take the example of Netflix or Uber. Who would have thought that brick and mortar business models, based on people buying their favorite DVDs from a local shop, or going to a car rental company, days in advance to your planned trip could be totally replaced?? With something that I cannot see, I haven't personally discussed and negotiated; yet so **EASY**!!

This easy is the key word. In today's world, we need everything fast, easy and yet which provides value to us. As a result, each company, every business is trying to imbibe and leverage Digital to provide more value to their customers. This shift has opened newer avenues for people, who are exploring different  programming languages, different technologies, learning and exploring. It's crucial to LEARN and EVOLVE to survive today and what challenges coming years  are going to throw at us. Resilience and adaptation to change has become a key metrics for success in any field.

Through this analysis, we will try to explore how the various people who responded to the survey this year are preparing themselves for this upcoming war of survival. Through several graphs, we will try to explore what is the distribution of people across age groups, profession groups etc. and what are the preferences. We will try to gauge what are the technologies to watch for, what are the things one need to arm themselves with to stay relevant. This is our own journey to equip ourselves with right tools and technologies for this disruptive digital transformation which has entered [Hadron Collider](https://home.cern/science/accelerators/large-hadron-collider)  growth phase and whether we like it or not we need to embrace this **impact**.

#  Top 5 ML Algorithms used by Kagglers

Here also **EASE** of use shows up as linear or logistic Regression as most popular choice. Decision Trees follow closely as next choice. The importance of data far exceeds any algorithm. Here is gist of various ML algorithms explained in a very simple way by [Elite Data sciences ](https://elitedatascience.com/machine-learning-algorithms). It clearly mentions that better data can beat fancier algorithms.

source.d7188683:
1. Technology is a powerful ally in today's global crisis. The ongoing pandemic has forced people, companies, countries to introspect and created this new urgency for Digital Transformation. This is the time when experts all around the world have one voice: DIGITIZE
2. Python is emerging to be the top choice for Data Scientist, owing to the EASE of learning
3. Cloud based Learning and Computing Platforms, like Kaggle and Colab are the gears to make your journey faster into Data Science Realm.
4. In the next 2 years, Google Cloud, Amazon Web Services, Azure Machine Learning, MongoDB, Tableau, PowerBI, Spotfire will be the most sought-after skills. More and more people are planning to invest, adapt and explore these budding technologies
5. With technologies like Big Data, Machine Learning, Business Analytics taking the front seat, the people and hence the businesses are moving forward at a pace that was never imagined before. BOLDLY GO INTO YOUR FUTURE!
source.ce847f83:
Kaggle and Colab Notebooks are starting point of Data Science Journey for most people, especially among the 25-39 age group. They provide a cloud computational environment that enables reproducible and collaborative analysis. Once again, it is **EASE** of use that is underlying reason behind their popularity. Kaggle is the most well-known competition platform for predictive modeling and analytics, according to  [kdnuggets](http://www.kdnuggets.com/2018/05/to-kaggle-or-not.html
)
source.3dba1e65:
# Is learning R/ Python modern pillars of Digital Transformation??

As per the 12 steps mentioned in [forbes Article](https://www.forbes.com/sites/blakemorgan/2020/04/05/is-covid-19-forcing-your-digital-transformation-12-steps-to-move-faster/?sh=44cd47a8617b) Covid-19 has forced this transformation and it is no longer CEO's or CTO's leading but it is current environment due to pandemic forcing us to be more adaptable to the changing times. That reminds us of famous quote from **Charles Darwin** "It is not the most intellectual of the species that survives; it is not the strongest that survives; but the species that survives is the one that is able to adapt to and to adjust best to the changing environment in which it finds itself".
The data shows irrespective of the profession Python holds the flag as tool for enabling this digital transformation.
source.c7708e96: Most of ML usage seems to be in "Nascent Phases" or "not yet using". But according to [Gartner](https://www.gartner.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/2019-07-15-gartner-survey-reveals-leading-organizations-expect-t) companies are expected to double number of AI projects
source.118fb2df: # Popular platforms where people start their Data Science Journey
source.25ce172e:
# Exploring the Age vs 'Coding Age'? Is there a preference of language that comes with coding experience?

SQL definitely seems to be choice for 20+ years of experience which shows as bog number for SQL in higher age groups, but Python seems to be clear choice everywhere else.
It does make sense as Python was created in the late 1980s, and first released in 1991, by Guido van Rossum as a successor to the ABC programming language. Being a young language, it has penetrated due to once again **EASE** of use.
source.711b6e11:
# Coding Language Preference among the entire group 

Python has emerged as language of choice irrespective of age, profession, gender any variable. Python’s huge ecosystem of rich libraries and implementation for various purposes makes it a genuinely more productive programming environment and multi-faceted option. It is simplicity and scalibility which makes python popular along with other benefits as explained in this [article](https://towardsdatascience.com/top-10-reasons-why-you-need-to-learn-python-as-a-data-scientist-e3d26539ec00). python is gradually becoming more popular than R and a [2017 article](https://www.datacamp.com/community/tutorials/r-or-python-for-data-analysis) clearly shows how percentage of users have increased year over year and inclined towards python
source.75a4580a: # Primary tool that you use at work or school to analyze data?

# Drill downing to understand what the top earning bracket use to code? Are these languages the ones I need to look up to stay ahead in the competition?

Python seems to dominate with SQL and Bash. We can also observe "other" as dominant category and languages like Julia, C++ and java have a small share for salaries >500000
